Description: Digital photograph (colour); view of painted, rock art on rock surface (sandstone?) showing figures of three human and two cattle figures. Centre: Cow, brown, upright and facing right with bowed head and pronounced udder with white teats. Portion of belly infilled in red. To right is upright human figure, facing right, in brown with arms bent and raised at elbow and red points on knees. Right of this, with hind legs superimposing neck and groin of human figure, is figure of cow in red , turned to side, facing down with belly to left. Calf of similar colour is to left as if standing under cow. Cow has grid-style coat pattern markings faintly visible on faded topline; no head visible on cow or calf. To right is human figure infilled in same colour, upright and facing left with bent left arm. Right: images of two cattle infilled in brown, turned to side with bellies at left, facing each other across similarly oriented human figure in same pigment, facing up with loop (arms?) emanating from chest. Bottom left: brown, infilled cow upright and facing right, cut off edge of image at hindquarters. Top: Small infilled black cow, turned to side and facing up with belly to left, head merged with hindquarters of another, similar, cut off edge of image at trunk. Right of this is similarly positioned bichrome cow figure with rump infilled in red and small horns. Between them is unidentified shape cut off edge of image. Karkur Talh, Sudan. Scanned
Curator's comments: Karkur Tahl is the largest wadi (dry seasonal riverbed valley) in the sandstone eastern section of Jebel Uweinat, a granite and sandstone massif on the border of Egypt, Libya and Sudan. Karkur Talh is around 25 km long and lies mostly in Sudan, but partly within Egypt’s borders. There is an abundance of both painted and engraved rock art in shelters in the smaller side wadis. The engravings were first revealed to academia by Ahmed Hassanein in 1923 and a few photographs published in his report on the journey in National Geographic in 1924. A more comprehensive publication of rock art sites in Karkur Talh was made by Prince Kemal el Dine with Abbe Breuil in 1925 following his discovery of a painted cave in Karkur Talh. Further exploration and publications were made by numerous others including renowned explorer Ralph Bagnold’s expedition in 1931, with further exploration from László Almásy and Leo Frobenius in 1933. The largest professional exploration of the massif to date was made in 1968 by a team of Belgian scientists.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
